content.description: From the rounded chockstone, climb the obvious hand crack leading up and first right before it jogs left and up to the belay ledge.
content.location: Right of Cornerstone on the Right Buttress, at the rounded chockstone in the bottom chimney.   Note that the rating is based on starting the climb here; many people use the chimney to bridge their way up to avoid the most difficult part of the crack. This reduces the route's difficulty to 5.7.

content.description: Make a committing move to gain the crack and follow it to its end. Step up and left slightly to gain a crescent-shaped crack and take it to its end. Another crescent-shaped crack lies tantalizingly out of reach, the crux is getting there. More tricky moves to top out.
content.protection: TR. This one may be leadable, but there are a couple spots where the pro would be too far below the leader's feet to avoid banging into the corner below.
content.location: At the bottom of the right buttress, on the side opposite Cornerstone's start. The prow overhangs prominently here; a long reach gains a thin crack running around the bulge from above.   Descent is by the Access Slot, the fourth class notch between the two major buttresses, or by walking west to the hiking trail.

content.description: Climb the face between Lost in the Crowd and Cornerstone's start. There's no pro to speak of, so it's pretty much a TR ride.   Lots of delicate moves most of the way up the face.
content.protection: A good belayer, or a stout heart.
content.location: Start at the same chockstone as Cornerstone

content.description: The outside of the largest prow has a "pillar" crack. Begin by standing on the boulder at the base of the prow (this is ~60' above the bottom). Gain the pillar and climb up the outside of the nose.   The pillar is a 7' tall block of rock less than 3' wide, sitting on a ledge. While it has been yanked on often, it is a bit unnerving!
content.protection: This route has been soloed. Protection behind the pillar is possible...but would it hold?
content.location: Summit ridge of Crane Mtn., right of the ladder, the outside arête of the tallest prow. Unmistakeable.

content.description: Climb up onto the pointed chockstone, then step up onto the face and move left to the arête. Climb the inside corner hidden on the nose to its end and the short, easy face above it to the top.
content.protection: Trad gear works well. The first move is committing but not difficult.
content.location: On the east side of the smaller of the two major buttresses. Generally top-roped by lowering the climber, the route can be led by walking ~200' east into the woods at the level area about 40' below the tall ladder. Look for a short face with two prominent cracks (Forest Crack 1 & 2), then continue right (east) to a tree-choked cone leading up to the chimney with the pointed chockstone.

content.description: Climb the crack to the top.   This is a good way to eeease people, especially young people, into climbing. It's short, but being on top of the summit ridge, there's a good sense of exposure.   Once a person climbs the crack, have him/her climb the face to the left, first with a hand on the crack's edge, then farther left.
content.location: On the east face of the left buttress, starting on the ledge closest to the top of the cliff in the Access Slot, at a crack about 7' left of the major corner.

content.description: To the right of the final ladder (a physical, wooden ladder) lie a few slabs with a few climbs, mostly good as top rope.
